title: Concert: Spektral Quartet—In Search of Futures Past: Schoenberg the Visionary
short_description: Spektral Quartet actively creates vivid conversations between exhilarating works of the traditional canon and those written this decade, this year, or this week.
header_description: Spektral Quartet actively creates vivid conversations between exhilarating works of the traditional canon and those written this decade, this year, or this week.
list_description: Discover Schoenberg’s impact on classical music in this program featuring a newly commissioned work by composer David Fulmer, Elliott Carter’s Fragments 1 and 2 and Arnold Schoenberg’s String Quartet no. 4, the composer’s final quartet.
description:
Discover Schoenberg’s impact on classical music in this program featuring a newly commissioned work by composer David Fulmer, Elliott Carter’s Fragments 1 and 2 and Arnold Schoenberg’s String Quartet no. 4, the composer’s final quartet. Following the concert, Jesse Rosenberg, Northwestern University associate professor of musicology, and museum educator Paulina Lopez discuss German expressionism in art and music.

About the Artist

Spektral Quartet actively creates vivid conversations between exhilarating works of the traditional canon and those written this decade, this year, or this week. Spektral is known for creating seamless connections across centuries and drawing in the listener with charismatic deliveries, interactive concert formats, an up-close atmosphere, and bold, inquisitive programming. In a review of a recent show, the New York Times wrote that “they have everything: a supreme technical command that seems to come easily; a capacity to make complicated music clear; and, most notably . . . an ability to cast a magic spell."

Nominated for a Grammy award and named “Chicagoans of the Year” by the Chicago Tribune in 2017, Spektral Quartet appears on the Sono Luminus, Azica Records, Nimbus Records, and Parlour Tapes+ labels, and is set to release a new album with saxophonist and MacArthur fellow Miguel Zenón in the summer of 2018. Recent residencies include Stanford University, New World Symphony, and Northwestern University, and the quartet is proud to serve as ensemble-in-residence for the University of Chicago’s Department of Music. Dubbed “The city’s hottest string quartet” by the Chicago Tribune, Spektral Quartet is committed to championing the work of Chicago composers around the world and reaching new audiences within the city limits through its partnership with Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation.

*Doors for the concert open at 1:30 and do not require museum admission.
